title: Magnetic flux - comparing loops near long wire

content.question: Four rectangular loops of wire are placed near a long wire that carries current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> to the left. Each rectangular loop has sides of length <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>a</mi></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2 a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mstyle></math> and is oriented relative to the wire as shown in the figure. The sides of loops <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> that are closest to the wire are the same distance from the wire. The center of Loop <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> is a very small distance adjacent to the wire. The magnetic fluxes through loops <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, and <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> are <math alttext="phi sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="phi sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="phi sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="phi sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, respectively, where magnetic flux into the page is positive. Which of the following correctly ranks the magnitude of the magnetic flux through the loops?

choices.label: <math alttext="phi sub 2 is greater than phi sub 1, which is greater than, which is greater than phi sub 3, which is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 4 equals 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="phi sub 1 equals phi sub 3, which is greater than phi sub 2, which is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 4 equals 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="phi sub 4 is greater than phi sub 2, which is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 1 equals phi sub 3, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="phi sub 2 is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 1 equals phi sub 3, close parenthesis, which is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 4 equals 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="phi sub 2 is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 1 equals phi sub 3, close parenthesis, which is greater than, open parenthesis, phi sub 4 equals 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
